item.title: How to reach out for help
item.description:
‚Üê News

Hi everyone!

You absolutely can (and should) reach out when you get stuck. I‚Äôm super responsive on Slack and e-mail. If you ask a question on the #help channel in Slack, others can help too. No question is too tricky or embarrassing, I promise. Computers are extraordinarily literal and tiny typos will often mess you up for a long time‚ÄîI‚Äôve lost countless time because of missing commas and misspelled words (curse you lenght()). Please feel comfortable reaching out.

Ask early and often

I‚Äôm a big believer in the 30 minute rule. If you‚Äôre stuck and not making progress on a task for 30 minutes, reach out for help from the community.

Be nice

One of the great parts about the online R community is that the team at RStudio has actually hired people to help promote community norms. Like that‚Äôs their whole job‚Äîcommunity evangelist (see @dataandme and @RachaelDempsey for instance). The R world is probably one of the nicest corners of the programming internet because of these norms‚Äîthere‚Äôs an emphasis on helping beginners, being kind and respectful, and cheerfully helping as much as possible. Watch the #rstats hashtag on Twitter, look at the ‚Äúr‚Äù tag on StackOverflow, and look at discussions at the RStudio Community and you‚Äôll see kindness in action.

This was not always the case. 10ish years ago, before the RStudio people made a concerted effort to create community, the online R world was pretty mean and toxic, with forums run by a few really grumpy statisticians who‚Äôd belittle you if you asked a poorly worded question. It was awful. That kind of attitude often still persists in other languages (hooo boy try asking a beginner question about Python at StackOverflow üò¨), but the R world has tried really hard to be welcoming.

I embrace that attitude when teaching R, and I encourage you all to do the same. Reach out for help early and often. Do not suffer in silence. Do not spend hours and hours stuck on an issue before reaching out for help. If you feel comfortable, reach out publicly on the #help channel rather than a Slack DM so that others can help. This helps build and strengthen the community within our class and within the R community more broadly.

Ask in a way that helps the answerer

There are a few easy guidelines to remember when asking for help:

  1. Be kind.

  2. Try asking questions with as complete information as possible. Rather than saying something like ‚Äúmy code isn‚Äôt working‚Äù and that‚Äôs it, provide more background (it‚Äôs hard to read your computer‚Äôs mind). Say specifically what you‚Äôre trying to do and provide code when possible. You can actually format R code on Slack if you click on the little lightning icon in the bottom left of the typing area and search for ‚Äútext snippet‚Äù‚Äîthat‚Äôll open a dialog that will let you paste in text and add R syntax highlighting. You can also paste your code between triple backticks on Slack and it‚Äôll format it in monospaced font (though not with the neat syntax highlighting that you get when using Slack‚Äôs text snippet thing):

    ```
ggplot(blah) + geom_point()
```

    You can also take screenshots (use ‚åò+shift+4 on macOS to save a screenshot to your Desktop, or ‚åò+‚å•+shift+4 to save a screenshot directly to the clipboard; use Windows+shift+S on Windows to save a screenshot directly to the clipboard). I‚Äôve had people send photos from their phones too. The one issue with screenshots/photos is that it‚Äôs harder for people to get the code out of Slack and into RStudio on their computer to troubleshoot, since you can‚Äôt copy/paste from an image.

  3. Try making your question a reproducible example (or reprex). Reprexes are the best way to (1) get help online and (2) fix issues on your own.

    Making a good reprex is tricky, but it‚Äôs a very valuable skill to know (regardless of programming language!). Here are some helpful resources for making them:

    • What‚Äôs a reproducible example (reprex) and how do I do one?
    • So you‚Äôve been asked to make a reprex
    • The reprex package

Don‚Äôt suffer in silence

And that‚Äôs it. Ask questions in ways that will help answerers answer them and be nice about it. When answering questions, be nice about it. Ask lots of questions. Answer lots of questions.

Once again, do not suffer in silence. I‚Äôve had past students tell me that‚Äôs like the one thing they‚Äôll remember from my classes‚Äîdo not suffer in silence. I mean it, and I‚Äôll keep saying it throughout the semester (because often in your past courses and degrees, you‚Äôve been discouraged from reaching out or from building communities or whatever‚Äîthat is not the case here).

item.title: Plan for the first day of class
item.description:
‚Üê News

Hi everyone!

Tomorrow‚Äôs the first day of class! Exciting!

Beyond hoping that everyone is wearing a mask, I‚Äôve structured the class in way that limits our exposure to each other as much as possible. As noted in the syllabus (https://evalf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/syllabus.html#course-structure), we‚Äôre using a flipped classroom this semester. What this means in practice is that you‚Äôll do all the readings and watch asynchronous lecture videos before class meets on Mondays.

Our in-person time will not involve lectures. Instead, it‚Äôll be a more hands-on lab for working with R and answering the questions that come up from doing the readings and watching the lectures. That‚Äôs the point of the weekly check-in assignment (https://evalf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/assignment/weekly-check-in.html)‚Äîthe only way this in-person time will be effective is if you do the readings + videos and ask questions in the weekly check-in.

The videos for the first day of class are live and ready to watch at https://evalf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/content/01-content.html (along with the readings). If possible, please watch them (and do the readings) before class on Monday so that we can start with the lab-like in-person time and get a good solid introduction to R and RStudio + answer the questions you have from the first session‚Äôs materials.

Ideally, please try to submit the first weekly check-in on iCollege by tomorrow too so that we can have some good Q&A time during our in-person time. BUT no worries if not!

If you don‚Äôt have time to get through the materials before the first day, that‚Äôs totally fine‚Äîyou can do it later and there‚Äôs no late penalty or anything for the first week, given that it is the first day of classes. But if you can, let‚Äôs get started!

item.title: Announcements and updates
item.description:
‚Üê News

One last thing!

Over the course of the semester, I‚Äôll be sending you lots of updates and announcements and FAQs based on your weekly check-ins.

My philosophy for this class is to let you maintain access to as much content as possible, which is why so little of the the class material is on iCollege.

I will post all these announcements and e-mails at the ‚ÄúNews section of the course website. This means that even after you finish the class and lose access to iCollege, and even after you graduate from GSU and lose access to your (gsu.edu?) e-mail address, you‚Äôll still have a searchable archive of messages and FAQs from this class.

I‚Äôll let you know when there‚Äôs a new item in the news section in a few different ways:

  1. I‚Äôll e-mail you a link to the newest message. I‚Äôll use the e-mail address you have listed in PAWS‚Äîif you want me to use a different address, let me know and I‚Äôll update my list,
  2. New messages should post automatically to the #general channel in Slack
  3. If you use an RSS feed reader (RIP Google Reader), you can subscribe to an RSS feed of the news section. There‚Äôs a link at the bottom of the news page.

Phew. That should be it from me for a while. Remember to read the syllabus and the rest of the course website, answer the welcome survey, sign up for Slack, and join the RStudio.cloud workspace. Also, remember to take care of yourselves! I mean every word in the ‚ÄúLearning during a pandemic‚Äù section of the syllabus. This all sucks so much, and I will try my hardest to accommodate your needs throughout the semester.

Thanks!

item.title: Important R stuff
item.description:
‚Üê News

From reading the syllabus you‚Äôll notice that we‚Äôre using R in this class (though you can certainly use Stata too if you really want). R is free (!!), and highly sought after by employers, but it has a little bit of an initial learning curve. You‚Äôll get the hang of it, though, I promise! I‚Äôm a certified RStudio instructor (see https://education.rstudio.com/trainers/), so I‚Äôve been specially trained to teach statistical programming. Again, I promise that you‚Äôll learn a ton.

You‚Äôll be doing your stats work in RStudio this semester. While R and RStudio are free and open source, they can sometimes be tricky to install. To make life simpler, you can run RStudio in your browser without having to install anything (!!!). Over the course of the semester you‚Äôll want to eventually install everything on your actual computer, since it‚Äôll run faster there, but you won‚Äôt need to install anything to get started. I‚Äôll e-mail you a link to join the class workspace.

In the meantime, you can also install everything on your actual computer if you follow these instructions (eventually you should do this‚Äîit‚Äôs best to run R on your own computer, but it‚Äôs totally fine to run everything at RStudio Cloud for the first few weeks)

If you have some free time over the next week and you feel like getting a head start, I would highly recommend going through a few of RStudio‚Äôs R Primers at https://rstudio.cloud/learn/primers. Don‚Äôt worry if you don‚Äôt have time to go through these introductory primers/tutorials! Your first problem set is essentially doing those primers (see here for the ones you‚Äôll need to do), so you don‚Äôt have to get a head start now if you don‚Äôt want to.

Once again, I promise that you can do this and have a blast in this class!

item.title: Welcome to class!
item.description:
‚Üê News

Hello everyone!

I‚Äôm Andrew Heiss, your professor for PMAP 8521 (Evaluation Research) this fall, and I‚Äôm so excited for the class! In this class you‚Äôll learn all about causal inference, or how to legally claim causation with statistics. In your past stats courses you were always taught ‚Äúcorrelation isn‚Äôt causation,‚Äù which is mostly true, except when it‚Äôs not. In this class you‚Äôll get to legitimately make causal claims.

We‚Äôll cover fun tools like directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), randomized controlled trials, difference-in-differences analysis, regression discontinuity analysis, and instrumental variables. You‚Äôll also learn the statistical language R, which is free (which means you can keep using it after you graduate and not have to pay for really really expensive SPSS or Stata licenses). I‚Äôve had former students get jobs because of the R part of this class‚Äîtons of organizations are looking for R skills nowadays.

I have a few important announcements before class:

  • We are meeting in person, but as you‚Äôll see in the syllabus (see the ‚ÄúMasking and vaccines‚Äù section there, I‚Äôm trying to take as many precautions as possible given the rapid spread of the BA.5 variant. For instance‚Ä¶

  • ‚Ä¶I‚Äôve made the course a flipped course, which means you‚Äôll do all the readings and watch the lectures on YouTube before class on Mondays. We‚Äôll spend our class time answering questions, doing activities, and learning a lot of R together. This means that the bulk of the course material is fully online and asynchronous.

  • Before class, I‚Äôd love to get to know each you a little first, so I‚Äôve created a quick survey to fill out. I‚Äôve sent you a link to it via e-mail. Please take it at your earliest convenience.

  • The entire course is available at a special class website at https://evalf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/. Bookmark this site‚Äîit‚Äôll be your best friend for the next semester. I only use iCollege for collecting your assignments, posting answer keys, posting a couple scanned book chapters, and offering the two exams (since it‚Äôs password protected). This website is the official source of dates and all other class information. Because it‚Äôs not part of iCollege, you‚Äôll be able to reference it even after you graduate and lose access to GSU resources. You can even share it with others‚Äîit‚Äôs just a website!

  • Please read the main explanatory pages at the course website at your earliest convenience. The instructions and expectations for the class are divided across different pages, all accessible from the menu bar at the top of the site. Please read the main pages for the syllabus, schedule, content, assignments, and examples.

  • We‚Äôre using zero physical textbooks in this class. Every reading and book and piece of software in this class is 100% free (see the syllabus for more information about that).

Quick background about me: I‚Äôm an assistant professor here at the Andrew Young School, where I‚Äôve been teaching MPA/MPP microeconomics, program evaluation, and data visualization. I moved here from Utah in 2019, where I was a visiting professor of public management at the Marriott School of Business at Brigham Young University (BYU). While at BYU, I taught microeconomics, statistics, and data visualization (basically the same stuff I‚Äôm teaching now). I finished my PhD in public policy and political science from Duke in 2017, and before then I finished my MPA in nonprofit management from BYU in 2012.

When I‚Äôm not teaching stats and evaluation, I research international nonprofits and political science. And when I‚Äôm not teaching or researching, I‚Äôm normally chilling at my house with my 6 (!!) kids (see https://www.heissatopia.com/ for photos and hilarious stories).

Again, I‚Äôm really excited to get started next week. This fall semester should be a blast!
